title: 104_hr3992
content: The "Medicare Commission Act of 1996" is established. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program is established with 15 members appointed by the President, Senate Majority Leader, and Speaker of the House of Representatives. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by the President, Senate Majority Leader, and Speaker of the House of Representatives. Members are appointed for the life of the Commission, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Appointments must be made within 3 months of the Act's enactment, and the initial meeting should take place within 30 days thereafter. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed for life, with vacancies filled in the same manner. The Commission must hold its initial meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and meetings will be called by the Chairman. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, and the Commission will select a Chairman from among its members. The Commission's duties are outlined in Section 3. The Commission is tasked with reviewing analyses of the Medicare trust funds, identifying solvency threats, analyzing potential solutions, and providing recommendations to ensure financial integrity and appropriate health benefits under the Medicare Program. The term "Medicare trust funds" refers to the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund. The Commission is responsible for reviewing the Medicare trust funds' solvency, identifying threats, analyzing solutions, and making recommendations. The Medicare trust funds refer to the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. The Commission's report must be submitted to the President and Congress within 12 months of its first meeting. Congressional leaders will consider legislation based on the Commission's recommendations within 3 months. The Commission will develop legislation for Medicare trust funds' long-term solvency within 3 months of submitting their report. If not voted on within 3 months in the House, the legislation will receive privileged consideration. If legislation introduced in the House or Senate is not voted on within 3 months, the respective committees will be discharged from consideration, and a motion to proceed will be highly privileged. If legislation introduced in the Senate is not voted on within 3 months, the committee will be discharged from consideration, and a motion to proceed will be privileged. If no vote on legislation within 3 months, it will be privileged in the Senate. Legislation introduced under paragraph (1)(A) must be considered and approved or disapproved within 3 months in the Senate or House of Representatives. If not, a joint resolution endorsing the report's recommendations and providing legislative authority must be considered. The Commission established by the Act has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, the Commission has authority over personnel matters. The Commission members who are federal government officers or employees serve without additional compensation. Private citizens on the Commission also serve without pay, but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Chairman of the Commission may appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairman can set their compensation independently. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can provide administrative support. Members of the Commission receive per diem for travel expenses. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and other personnel, set their compensation, and detail government employees without reimbursement. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured at specified rates. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and other personnel, set their compensation, and detail government employees without reimbursement. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured at specified rates without interruption of civil service status or privilege. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its report. Funding for the Commission will be paid from available funds to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
